review: I purchased this and a Roku 2 with the faster processor, this stick is completely useless for me.  First off it doesn't even work with any of my TVs and its suppose to work with any HDMI set.  I tried it with a friends TV and it does indeed work so I know the unit itself is okay.  When I did use it the performance is just awful, the menu lag is simply unacceptable.  The original Roku years ago was faster than this.  Why they bother to sell such a thing is beyond me.  Plus, my intentions were to replace older AppleTVs and switch to Plex for all my media on my media server and this low powered stick wouldn't even play any of my true 1080p content in Plex or the other local media streaming apps.  Files that play wonderfully on the newer version of the Roku 2.  Don't waste your time on this and just spend a little more on a Roku 2 or 3 with the faster CPU, I promise you won't be disappointed.
author: CynicalDooDad

review: This is my second Roku. I love 'em. I bought the stick because I've mounted the TV on the wall. The Roku works well.My trouble is with the remote. As it must be, it's a radio-frequency device (most remotes are infrared, requiring line of sight), but I live in a large apartment house and WiFi routers are everywhere. Occasionally, the remote can't find the stick due to strong interference from other WiFi's and stops working. I could change the channel that my router is using, but I'm planning to move in three days to an area where WiFi interference probably won't be as severe so the problem may go away. Meanwhile the app on my phone works as a remote just fine -- when my phone happens to be nearby.My point: If you live in a densely-populated area (there are over 200 apartments in my building), you may experience remote outages due to WiFi Interference.BTW: I learned of the WiFi interference thing (and got the suggestion to change the router's channel) from Roku support, which was quite good.
author: Tom in Portland
